image.altText: Police walking in the Alice Springs CBD.

props.synopsis: The NT government will today decide whether the youth curfew in Alice Springs, initially announced for two weeks and due to end Wednesday, will be extended.

title.children: Decision on possible extension of youth curfew in Alice Springs expected today

image.altText: Two women, one holding a young child.

props.synopsis: For the first time, Kumanjayi Petrick's family speak about their loss, one month since the stolen car crash that took his life and sparked violent unrest in Alice Springs.

title.children: Alice Springs family speaks out about town's violence after fatal crash of teenage relative

image.altText: Bespectacled woman with brown hair and yellow top sitting standing in front of new smart power meter

props.synopsis: Economists love them. Regulators say they make the grid more efficient. But many Australians are finding out time-of-use tariffs mean sharply higher power prices.

title.children: Anger and despair as electricity customers shifted to 'punishing' tariffs

image.altText: Marles and a man in navy uniform stand in a courtyard, an Australian flag behind them.

props.synopsis: Vice-Admiral David Johnston will lead Australia's armed forces as chief of the defence force, pending the approval of the governor-general.

title.children: Vice-Admiral David Johnston named new chief of the defence force

image.altText: An X-ray printout showing a pelvis with two hips replaced.

props.synopsis: Smart people are getting caught out on private health insurance — so do they need to be more savvy, or does the system need to change?

title.children: Australians seeking hip replacements tripped up by health insurance fine print

image.altText: A man and a woman stand on a beach with their arms around each other. They have grave expressions on their faces.

props.synopsis: Peter Correy was tricked into sending $450,000 to an Australian oil company. A financial crime expert warns criminals are exploiting weaknesses in Australia's regulatory system to get away with laundering.

title.children: 'We were scammed, he was scammed': How criminals used an Australian company to launder money

image.altText: Illustration of a women in blue clothes holding a baby with a bandaged head against a black grey background

props.synopsis: One Monday late last year I received a call from the Australian Red Cross: "What would you say about going to Gaza?" I didn't hesitate. Sometimes I wonder why I have no fear.

title.children: 'What would you say about going to Gaza?': This is why I didn't hesitate

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu wearing suit stands in front of flag of Israel

props.synopsis: Details of an agreement struck between Australia and Israel on defence industry cooperation will not be released publicly over concerns the information could damage Australia's "international relations".

title.children: Details of defence deal with Israel kept under wraps to protect Australia's 'reputation'

image.altText: A man and woman hugging in front of a for sale sign at a house

props.synopsis: The issue of housing affordability in Australia was once confined almost entirely to home ownership, but has now boiled over into the rental market. Is it even possible to unwind a property bubble that's been two decades in the making?

title.children: Will the housing affordability crisis eat us up?

image.altText: A submarine with a red, white and blue flag on the front sits on an empty patch of concrete

props.synopsis: Australia and its AUKUS partners, the US and UK, are considering including Japan in some of the alliance's advanced technology projects, the three countries' defence ministers confirm.

title.children: China 'gravely concerned' as Australia, US, UK confirm Japan being considered for AUKUS

image.altText: Steve Edgington stands in front of the white closed double gate of the Juno Center with his hands on his hips.

props.synopsis: The Tennant Creek agricultural learning space will be used as an interim youth justice facility while a permanent site for young people awaiting bail and sentencing is built.

title.children: Juno Centre to become temporary home for young people awaiting bail

image.altText: Ella Mason poses for a photo with a medicine ball on their shoulder, at Pony Club Gym in Melbourne.

props.synopsis: Building muscle isn't just for powerlifters and body builders. These experts explain how some resistance training, even just at home, can impact how we experience ageing.

title.children: This exercise has a huge effect on our health and longevity, but many of us ignore it

image.altText: A man wearing special glasses over his eyes.

props.synopsis: A total solar eclipse sees millions of people across North America watch as the Moon completely blocks the Sun, for more than four minutes in some places.

title.children: Millions take in total solar eclipse across North America

image.altText: Man in military uniform.

props.synopsis: A criminal investigation could be launched into the drone strikes that killed Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom, says an IDF spokesperson who calls the incident "clearly a mistake".

title.children: 'Must be Hamas': IDF spokesperson launches defence of drone strikes that killed Australian aid worker

image.altText: Above-the-head shot of a dozen people walking down a street next to bombed buildings turned to rubble

props.synopsis: Hamas rejects an Israeli ceasefire proposal made at talks in Cairo, while Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announces a date has been set for an invasion of Rafah, Gaza's last refuge for displaced Palestinians.

title.children: 'There is a date': Benjamin Netanyahu says invasion of Rafah will go ahead, ceasefire talks stall

image.altText: A young man leans on the open door of a car.

props.synopsis: Conflict in the Middle East and Ukraine, improved economic conditions in the US and China and cuts to production have combined to drive the price of crude oil up. Converted to petrol and diesel, it's shipped to Australia, and the cost of it is only going one way: up.

title.children: Consumers feel the pinch as fuel set to get more expensive in the coming weeks and months

image.altText: Scott Morrison with Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare

props.synopsis: A strongly worded document from Tonga's Foreign Affairs Ministry gives insight into the Pacific nation's view of Australia and New Zealand's diplomatic efforts.

title.children: Leaked documents show Australia and New Zealand's 'condescending rhetoric' to 'Pacific family' in response to China-Solomons security pact

image.altText: A photo of Lani. She is in her early 20s, has fair skin, blue eyes and long blonde hair.

props.synopsis: Workers employed under awards, who also provide care to loved ones with ongoing conditions, say a "cumbersome and burdensome" leave process has left them struggling to get basic entitlements.

title.children: 'I left my job because of it': Workers who care for loved ones say leave requirements require too much paperwork

image.altText: A mechanical piece of equipment - an electrolyser - on display on a table.

props.synopsis: The Gladstone Electrolyser Facility in central Queensland will be the first facility in Australia to build electrolysers at a commercial scale.

title.children: What are hydrogen electrolysers and can they help lead Australia to a fossil fuel-free future?

image.altText: A woman with short dark hair inspects cannabis plants on a farm.

props.synopsis: About 140,000 Australians are prescribed cannabis to help manage pain and illness, but the industry says cheap imports aren't regulated properly.

title.children: Australian medicinal cannabis growers 'in trouble' as imported product squeezes the industry

image.altText: The cast of All That at the 2003 Nickelodeon Kids Choice Awards

props.synopsis: The four-part documentary series features candid interviews with former child stars and Nickelodeon employees about the conditions they experienced working for the network.

title.children: Quiet on Set exposed the concerning conditions at Nickelodeon and it has more to say

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The ASX opens higher, with a quiet day expected before key US inflation data is released on Wednesday. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX opens higher, Ken Henry says Australia has 'colonial economic structure'

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: IMF: Interest rate rises hurt Australians more than borrowers in other countries
Ken Henry says Australia has a 'colonial' economy with an 'antiquated' tax system

image.altText: A graphic with the background of an outback town. On the next layer a woman and a man at desks and a woman serving sausages.

props.synopsis: Community legal centres from the bush to the CBD are reporting difficulty in hiring and maintaining legal staff, as pay lags behind the legal aid commissions and government positions.

title.children: 'We're doing a sausage sizzle': Community legal centres taking desperate measures to pay staff

image.altText: Road slippage at Megalong Road in the Megalong Valley cuts access to the area

props.synopsis: Up to 150 trapped Megalong Valley residents could have a way out by the end of the week, according to the local mayor who is hopeful a temporary road will be approved by engineers today.

title.children: 'Everyone is stressed, worried, anxious': Community trapped by landslide given hope of way out this week

image.altText: Pope Francis speaks into a microphone while reading from a sheet of paper

props.synopsis: The Vatican declares sex reassignment operations and surrogacy as grave threats to human "dignity", putting them on par with abortion and euthanasia as practices that violate God's plan for human life.

title.children: Vatican condemns sex reassignment surgery, surrogacy and gender theory as threats to human 'dignity'

image.altText: Virginia Trioli, a woman in her 50s, and Trent Dalton, a man in his 40s, smile together, Dalton with his arms behind his back.

props.synopsis: In the premiere episode of Creative Types, Trent Dalton, the bestselling author of Boy Swallows Universe,  shows host Virginia Trioli around the city that shaped him: Brisbane.

title.children: 'Creativity saved my life': Trent Dalton's journey from a rough area to bestselling author

image.altText: Two costumed performers embrace during a show.

props.synopsis: Dark Mofo has been credited with turning Tasmania's traditionally quiet winter into a must-visit season. But the festival is having a year off this year, and other festivals are ending, so what will that mean for tourism?

title.children: Half a million people visit Tasmania in winter, will they still come without Dark Mofo?

image.altText: A man in a blue suit, white shirt and blue and white stripped tie looks at the camera and pumps his fist

props.synopsis: In the video, Donald Trump says he supports exceptions for rape, incest and to protect the life of the mother.

title.children: Donald Trump says US states should handle abortion law, stopping short of suggesting a national ban in new video

image.altText: Kyle Langford

props.synopsis: Kyle Langford says Jeremy Finlayson's homophobic slur is "unacceptable" and compares the matter to racial abuse in sport.

title.children: Dons forward Langford compares homophobic slur to racial abuse as Finlayson faces investigation

image.altText: A rail line with the soil washed out from under it.

props.synopsis: Residents say they are grappling with all too familiar frustrations after severe weather in New South Wales damaged the South Coast rail line and exposed insurance vulnerabilities in the region.

title.children: South Coast trains remain offline after flooding exposes railway track's fragility

image.altText: Three people walk towards a press conference and awaiting cameras.

props.synopsis: The trio of incoming Jacqui Lambie Network members say they are ready to hold the balance of power in the Tasmanian Parliament — acknowledging that although they "don't know how to use it" they will "learn quick".

title.children: 'It's wild': Three 'just normal people' are now kingmakers in a parliament they've never set foot in

image.altText: a piece of sugarcane broken in half on top of a bowl of sugar

props.synopsis: Scientists have mapped the genome of sugar cane and the hope is that farmers will be able to grow the versatile crop to make biofuel.

title.children: Scientific breakthrough on sugar cane genome maps out green fuel future

image.altText: Black sign which reads OTR no exit, as a bus passes behind it.

props.synopsis: Service station giant OTR agrees to pay back — or credit — $2.3 million in annual leave entitlements to 1,500 current and former employees across multiple states after a Fair Work Ombudsman investigation.

title.children: OTR denied 1,500 workers $2.3m in annual leave entitlements, ombudsman says

image.altText: Ollie Hoare looks emotional while wearing an Australian running kit

props.synopsis: Struggles with his mental health almost drove Australian running champion Olli Hoare to retire. Now, he's "crushing workouts" in an Olympic year, ready to launch assaults on Adelaide and Paris.

title.children: Anxiety and depression almost drove Olli Hoare to retire. Now the champion runner has an eye on Paris
